description.narrative:
Sweden has supported the UNRCO since 2011. The original agreement for phase I was between 2011-2013. An addendum was made in February 2013 to support a phase II for another two years between April 2013 - April 2015. Two crucial posts have been recruited and fully funded during these years; a strategic planning specialist (also Head of UNRCO) and a communication specialist. Apart from these positions, the Swedish funding has also contributed to joint UN planning and implementation excercises during phase I and II. In the budget for phase II of the project, funds was secured for an in-depth project assessment, managed by UNRCO but carried out by an external consultant.
Given that the UN System in Zimbabwe is embarking on a new programme from 2016 to 2020, and in order for the UNCT to successfully fulfil its mandate, sustained coordination capacities in the UNRCO are essential. A three year strategy is therefore proposed, building on the Sweden supported project Support to UN coherence efforts in Zimbabwe phase I and II, whereby the human and technical resources of the UNRCO would be sustained and enhanced. With increased focus on joint programming, advocacy and communications, resources in this project will continue to significantly complement resources provided by other partners, UN Agencies in Zimbabwe and by UN Headquarters. In addition, this project will focus only on human resource capacity, with joint UN activities now funded only by UN HQ and the UN Country Team.

The project's overall objective is to ensure that the necessary capacities and resources are made available to the UN Resident Coordinator and UN Country Team to better implement the Zimbabwe United Nations Development Assistance Framework, by hiring a Strategic Planning Advisor and a communication specialists.

The project "Support to UN coherence efforts in Zimbabwe III" has the overall objective of ensuring that the gains made by the UN in Zimbabwe during the implementation of phase I and II (2011-2018) are consolidated in a sustainable manner. The project support the coherent implementation of the 2016-2020 ZUNDAF with a focus on Delivering as One, through increased joint programming efforts.

sector.narrative: Multisector aid for basic social services

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The Swedish support started in 2011 and has for 7-8 years covered almost 2/3 (64%) of the total budget of the UN RC Office. This poses a high risk, not least for UNRCO, which has been heavily dependent on Swedish support for a long time. A lot of activities have taken place during this period, as well as inter-action between the UNRCO and the Swedish Embassy. The support has also included funding of staff in the UNRCO including core staff as the post as Head of Office.It is however challenging to assess wheter the objectives have been met, since they are focussing on more sustainable long term impact likeensuring consolidation in a sustainable manner, and increased joint programming efforts.While reporting has mainly focussed on more short term implementation of activities. It has not been possible to find an independent external evaluation that could otherwise have been very useful to further assess the impact of the support. With the official adoption of Delivering as One approach as an enabler, the Joint UN Partnership and Resource Leveraging Strategy 2016-2020 was finalized already in 2016. A Mid-Year Review of the 2016-2020 ZUNDAF has shown that ZUNDAF delivery is on target, projected at USD 400 million per annum. SDGs are mainstreamed into the ZUNDAF, therefore, ZUNDAF is the main vehicle for SDGs implementation for the UN in Zimbabwe.UN is also jointly supporting the Government reform efforts, as well as support to both duty-bearers and rights-holders on human rights. Under the UNCT Human Rights Group, the UN report's it has provided support to the Government and civil society’s effective participation in the UPR process.In the area of advocacy and communications, the RCO has enhanced visibility of the UN, its work and its core principles and values in the media and the public sphere. Coordinating the UN agencies to do more concreat advocacy for developemnt as well as trageting policy support. The focus has primarily been on sustained Policy Advice and Coordination Support. The RCO has also coordinated the efforts of the WB-UN country wide asessements. Also, the RCO has coordinated work around the Spotlight Initiative in regards to combate gender based violence. Apart from that, the Embassy has had a close working relationship with other UN bodies, notably UNICEF, UNFPA, UN Women and UNDP - where programs and projects are being supported, implemented and followed up in close dialogue.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
